org.strongback.components

Interface Clock

  • Functional Interface:
    This is a functional interface and can therefore be used as the assignment target for a lambda expression or method reference.

    @FunctionalInterface
public interface Clock
    The system that provides information about match time.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      long currentTimeInMicros()
      Return the current time, in microseconds.
      default long currentTimeInMillis()
      Return the current time, in milliseconds.
      default long currentTimeInNanos()
      Return the current time, in nanoseconds.
      static Clock fpga()
      Create a new time system that uses the FPGA clock.
      static Clock fpgaOrSystem()
      Create a new time system that uses the FPGA clock if it is available, or the JRE's time system if not.
      static Clock system()
      Create a new time system that uses the JRE's System clock.

    • Method Detail

      • currentTimeInMicros

        long currentTimeInMicros()
        Return the current time, in microseconds.
        Returns:
        the elapsed time, in microseconds

      • currentTimeInNanos

        default long currentTimeInNanos()
        Return the current time, in nanoseconds.
        Returns:
        the elapsed time, in nanoseconds

      • currentTimeInMillis

        default long currentTimeInMillis()
        Return the current time, in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        the elapsed time, in milliseconds

      • fpga

        static Clock fpga()
        Create a new time system that uses the FPGA clock. At this time, the precision of the resulting clock has not been verified or tested.
        Returns:
        the FPGA-based clock; never null
        Throws:
        StrongbackRequirementException - if the FPGA hardware is not available

      • fpgaOrSystem

        static Clock fpgaOrSystem()
        Create a new time system that uses the FPGA clock if it is available, or the JRE's time system if not.
        Returns:
        the FPGA-based clock or (if that is not available) the system clock; never null

      • system

        static Clock system()
        Create a new time system that uses the JRE's System clock. The performance and precision of the JVM clock depends upon the accuracy and precision of the underlying platform's mechanism for returning absolute and relative time. Absolute time can be obtained via currentTimeInMillis(), although precision on some platforms may be as low as 10 or 20 milliseconds. Relative time that can be compared within a single process can be obtained via currentTimeInNanos() and currentTimeInMicros(), although again the precision may be at best around 10 or 20 microseconds.

        Additionally, care must be taken when using relative time on multi-core systems. Because relative time often uses the CPU's clock, relative time obtained from different CPUs might not be comparable. This is possible even if using a single thread, since the same thread might be scheduled on a different CPU after switching thread contexts.

        Returns:
        the system clock; never null
